name: Rasgulla
history: Rasgulla is believed to have originated in West Bengal and is a classic example of Indian milk-based sweets. It has been a part of Indian cuisine for centuries and is a staple in Bengali celebrations.
description: Rasgulla is a soft, spongy ball made from chhena (an Indian cottage cheese) and semolina dough, cooked in a light sugar syrup. It's known for its delicate texture and sweet, milky flavor.

equipment.name: large pot
equipment.description: For boiling the milk and cooking the rasgullas.

instructions.title: Make the Chhena
instructions.description: Boil the milk in a large pot. Once it comes to a boil, add lemon juice or vinegar to curdle the milk. Once the milk solids separate, strain through a muslin cloth.

instructions.title: Knead the Dough
instructions.description: Knead the chhena with semolina until it forms a smooth dough. Divide and shape into small, smooth balls.

instructions.title: Prepare the Syrup
instructions.description: In the same pot, dissolve sugar in water and bring it to a boil. Add cardamom powder for flavor.

instructions.title: Cook the Rasgullas
instructions.description: Gently drop the balls into the boiling syrup. Cook for about 10-15 minutes until they double in size and become spongy.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Remove the rasgullas from the syrup and let them cool. Serve chilled.

tips: Ensure the chhena is moisture-free before kneading to achieve the right texture.
While cooking, the rasgullas should have enough space to expand in the pot.
variations: Ras Malai: Flatten the rasgullas and soak them in thickened, sweetened milk.
Flavored Rasgulla: Infuse the syrup with saffron or rose water for a different taste.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 5 days.
storage.instructions: Store in syrup in an airtight container.

reheatingInstructions: Not applicable, as rasgullas are served chilled.
presentationTips: Serve in a bowl with some syrup and garnish with chopped pistachios or almonds.
For a festive touch, garnish with edible silver leaf (varq).
